instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2530: What is 820-2530? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.PP1V05_S5: What is PP1V05_S5? PP1V05_S5 is a 1.05v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. On 2008-2009 15” and 17” Macbook boards, this often gets stuck at 0.3v due to a bad C7771 capacitor. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> comes from MCP but what's powering the MCP?

threads.message: PPBUS? <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>? PP1V05? <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> toggles when you short power pad? <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> high? 32KHz at RTC Xtal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I have green light so i have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3_HOT</SIGNAL> and o have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> also i have 3.3v for <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> IS 3.3v and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S5</SIGNAL> i have but i don have so state on PP1V05

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2530</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Green light is nothing to do with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ..... Unless I am just reading your post wrong.

Green light is PP3V42. It's a data line, so "logic level" which = 0 ~ 5V which is why 3V42 line is used.
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> can be 0V and you'll still have 3V42 green / orange light... Providing the pull ups are in value and the SMC is working.

Post values, they can't help you without values ;)
